result.reason: Highly requested feature (20+ comments, maintainer acknowledged) to use Windows native OpenSSH instead of PuTTY for SSH connections, eliminating bundled PuTTY dependency
result.approach: Add new OpenSSH protocol provider that launches native ssh.exe (C:\Windows\System32\OpenSSH\ssh.exe) and embeds the console window, similar to how PuttyBase embeds PuTTY. Create OpenSshBase class parallel to PuttyBase with conhost embedding. Add SSH provider selection in connection settings (PuTTY vs OpenSSH). Support .ssh/config integration and key-based auth without Pageant.

attempts.raw_output:
This is a significant feature request â€” adding native OpenSSH as an alternative SSH provider to replace PuTTY. The SSH protocol implementation (`ProtocolSSH1`, `ProtocolSSH2`) currently inherits from `PuttyBase`, which handles all the PuTTY process management and embedding. Supporting native OpenSSH would require a new protocol base class for console-based SSH, terminal embedding (conhost/Windows Terminal integration), and significant changes to connection handling.

This is a major architectural enhancement, highly requested (many +1s, comments from 2018-2025), and a maintainer (Kvarkas) confirmed they're looking into removing PuTTY dependency. Given the scope (new protocol provider, terminal embedding, SSH config support), this is a P3 enhancement with substantial implementation effort.
